headline: Trump says he removed Bolton, Bolton claims he resigned
subHeadline: Feud over White House shake-up; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello everybody. I'm Jesse Watters along with Kennedy, Juan Williams, Dana Perino, and Tom Shillue. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is “The Five.” Breaking news out of the White House, John Bolton is out as national security advisor. We'll have a lot more on that coming up. But first, a new embarrassment for CNN after yet another Russia bombshell completely implodes. The CIA hammering the network's latest story as misguided and simply false, and the White House says that CNN could be putting lives in danger. Here's what happened. CNN claiming the CIA was forced to extract a high level spy inside Russia in 2017 because President Trump mishandled classified intelligence and risk exposing the person's identity. The network pumped it up like crazy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: U.S. intelligence pulled a very high level agent, a spy, out of Russia, in part, out of concerned the president might somehow blow this individual's cover.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: A move driven in part by concern that President Trump and his administration repeatedly mishandled classified intelligence.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: In part, because of concerns the president could have expose the asset. That's really shocking.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But it turns out, that's not exactly true. Multiple outlets, including Fox News, reporting that President Trump had nothing to do with it. Instead, the spy was pulled out because of concerns about media reporting around Russia election interference. The decision was also made before Trump even took office. Former CIA director turn secretary of state, Mike Pompeo, slamming CNN over the report earlier.

utterances.speaker: MIKE POMPEO, SECRETARY OF STATE
utterances.sentences: The reporting is materially inaccurate and you should know. As the former CIA director, I don't talk about things like this very often. It is only the occasions where there's something that I think puts people at risk or the reporting is so egregious as to create enormous risk at the United States of America that I even comment in a way that I just did. The reporting there is factually wrong.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, Dana, it's not just that they got this wrong, it potentially put lives in danger. Again, yet another false story by CNN about Trump and Russia.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.sentences: Let's be clear, lives could still be in danger, maybe even more so now. This is supposed to be a news story, not an episode of the Americans. And I understand the frustration of the Central Intelligence Agency. CIA hardly ever comments on anything. Now, if you call a reporter on background and you say, hey, I've got this tip. What do you think about? Now, one of the things the CIA communications person might say is, I am telling you off the record, you are wrong. You will be embarrassed if you print that. Don't go with it. I'm waving you off the story. Or you might say, I have no comment for you on that and I will let you know if I ever do. Those two things can give you some clarification. Sounds to me like the CIA and the State Department are both very much on the same page saying this did not happened. We also know that Putin has not been shy about punishing his enemies or former spies. Let's go to Britain and we'll roll the tape and you've got problems there. It not only hurts the people that are targeted, but those around them because of the poison that they have used. So this is extremely dangerous. Disappointed -- I don't know what happened there with all of the reporting, but obviously, it was not good enough.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, Juan, what do you think happened? And do you think the leaks are real but the news is wrong?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.sentences: No. I think -- this is really interesting. I really appreciate what Dana had to say, because I think what Dana just told you is an insight into how public, you know, press secretary handle reporters when we're asking these kinds of questions on sensitive stories. They basically tell you if you're right or wrong. So CNN breaks the story. The story is then followed up by the New York Times and the Washington Post. Russia's state-sponsored media also at that point says they have the name of this spy.   The New York Times in their reporting, which comes after, separate from the CNN story. And the New York Times, by the way, said the CNN story was wrong. But the New York Times said, we've checked with someone like a Dana Perino, and they didn't wave us off this story. They said, go ahead. So that tells you that there is basis to the reality of this person, this spy, former -- apparently someone who was high up in the Russian government, close enough to Putin to have access to documents that he could then -- not only see, but in some cases photograph and sent to the U.S. And then you get the general anxiety that comes after Trump's meeting in 2017 with the Russian ambassador and the Russian foreign minister. That's a separate issue. Initially, this guy was tried -- they tried to, what they call, expatriate this man in 2016 after Washington Post, New York Times story said the U.S. government has a source inside the Kremlin.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: They -- he refused to leave. But then, there's this increased anxiety after the Trump oval office meeting with the Russians, and then the guy agrees to leave and he's pulled. But it's not because of Trump.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, again, it's not Trump putting national security at risk, Kennedy. It's the media.

utterances.speaker: LISA KENNEDY MONTGOMERY, HOST
utterances.sentences: Well, and we're also taking a leap there. And, you know, there may have been something untoward and not right about that meeting. There may have been something very un-presidential about the president's comportment in that meeting. That doesn't mean that the president somehow reveal the identity of this asset in Russia to the ambassador when he was in the White House. And that is -- that is the unfortunate leap. And perhaps, that's the thing that takes time and clarification, because right now, for places like CNN, it's really, choose your own adventure. And if you get some facts that are not correlated or really directly tied to the ultimate conclusion, you just go ahead and make it up. You just go ahead and craft a bridge out of your own intentions, regardless of their truth or falsehood. And that's what's most dangerous.  And I think part of it is this desire to bring the president down and really pin something on him. Because, you know, your intuition is telling you that something is not right. It could be your hurt feelings. However, you know, going ahead and just throwing anything at him, regardless of facts, it's dangerous.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And Rush Limbaugh weigh in earlier about how all this Russia reporting has affected the media.

utterances.speaker: RUSH LIMBAUGH, TALK SHOW HOST
utterances.sentences: I think that that little episode is going to have a price that they're not even calculating. There will be a price to pay for this. And the Democrats are seen as being responsible for it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Tom Shillue, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: TOM SHILLUE, HOST
utterances.sentences: Well, I would hope that Rush is right about that, but there never seems to be a price for it. And, you know, they don't seem to think there's a price for it, because they keep doing these stories. They keep wanting to reopen these Russia things. So -- and you know what, the rest of the mainstream media lets them get away with it. They always say, well, that ship has sailed. The Russia story is over. I mean, it's a massive scandal and I think President Trump, he's going to try to make hay out of this and we're going to be talking about it later on the show.   And his rally last night, he was talking about the Democrats and the media together. There a twosome. And that's what he's talking about that the Democrats and the media are -- have been acting as one, and he's going to use that when he runs against them in 2020.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The other thing is -- you're not solid on this and you go with it. That aside -- for a second, think of how amazing our intelligence agencies are, that they were able to get this asset that close.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All around the world. And I understand the appeal to want to report on one of these stores. I don't know how far up they went. Right now, if the CIA said, you know, go ahead. I don't know. Well, I would -- I would want to track that down and just see. And maybe they thought that they couldn't comment on it or they're trying to protect the identity. There's so many things that you don't know. But the dangers of it hurting other national security efforts I think to me are so great. I would air on the side of caution.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: Well, and also, you bring up a really good point and that is, you know, we have relied so much on things like drones and mass surveillance and not enough on human beings and cultivating those relationships. And it doesn't matter who the administration is or who the president is, those things take time and we do need to cultivate those assets more and more around the world. And also, every time we focus on Russia, we really take our eyes off of other countries who might be trying to infiltrate our elections and our voting systems based on the road map that Russia laid out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, lastly, do you think that CNN should apologize and retracts the way that Lawrence O'Donnell had to with his other fake Russia reporting two weeks ago.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, it's totally different, Jesse, in the sense that Lawrence O'Donnell -- I think he said he had one source that wouldn't go on the record and it was very flimsy. I just -- I don't think that was journalism.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.sentences: It is similar. I mean, that's what he said. According to a person familiar with the talks, that was all I saw in the CNN article that I read according to a person familiar with the talks.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't believe that.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.sentences: It's one flimsy source.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't believe that, but if it's the case, then that would be flimsy, Tom. But I don't believe that they would have --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I mean, it's a pattern, Juan. I mean, they reported that Don Jr. has access to WikiLeaks when he didn't have access prior to the release. They fired several reporters from their investigative unit over the false reporting about Scaramucci ties to Russia --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, and also -- if you're looking at the media writ large as Rush Limbaugh was doing, you remember the story was Lawrence O'Donnell just a couple of weeks ago, but that was MSNBC in which they went with a single source and then he has to apologize the next day, oh, I shouldn't have done that. It was also Russia related.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But here's the thing to me. I think what you hear from the intelligence agency, they didn't like the presidents meeting with the Russians in the oval office. That's for sure. Then a couple of weeks ago it's the president tweeting out a picture of an Iranian site and saying, oh, he knows and people like -- isn't that classified, Mr. President? What are you doing?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But he gets to decide.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: He's the one who decides, but --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- but for the intelligence agencies, Dana, they're worried. They're saying, hey, can you trust this president to protect us and to protect our assets. Here's the thing I want to say to you, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Now that we know so clearly about this person, this spy, working for the United States at the upper reaches of Putin's government, we know that there was far more than the Steele dossier, far more than anything we've known before in terms of proof that the United States government had about Russian interference in the 2016 election being directed by Vladimir Putin, and the basis therefore for an investigation, not only into Russian interference but into Russian ties to --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm glad you brought that up, Juan, because --

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: -- President Obama revealed some of that earlier.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, Juan, I'm glad you brought that up because we're now looking at testimony that proves that the Steele dossier was the basis for launching --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, it wasn't. Obviously not. Obviously not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- the FBI counterintelligence investigation into the Trump campaign. You'll see, Juan. Coming up, a shake-up in the White House, the breaking details ahead.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: A major shake-up at the White House today. John Bolton is out as national security advisor. And now, he's in a back-and-forth with the president about how it happened. Trump tweeted earlier that he fired Bolton. But Bolton, he quickly responded that he wasn't fired, instead he said he resigned. Who's telling the truth here, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't know what's happened. But, I mean, the guy has had a very good career, very well respected, professional guy, but it just didn't work out. It had been shimmering for a long time. It was probably personality and a little ideology. He didn't play well with a lot of people in the sandbox. Academics sometimes don't. He didn't have a lot of allies. He clashed with Pompeo. He clashed with Mike Pence. So, sorry, that role as national security advisor too, you're in close contact with the President of the United States often in the oval office. And you have to be able to mesh. I don't think he meshed. And what the president wanted was someone to implement his policies, execute his strategies and his directives. And it seemed like a lot of the times, Bolton was saying, oh, well, you know what, this is why my ideas better, and that's just not going to work. There's three huge things that are on the horizon, the president needs to turn the page on in foreign policy, the China trade deal, Afghanistan, and Iran. And all those three things he's gonna need seasoned pro that can navigate those three things without a lot of turbulence and land that plane, because next year, year and a half, two years is going to be big.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know, Dana, I think lots of people saw John Bolton as a strong conservative voice in the administration. I think the president hired him for just that reason. And now, it turns out, he's on the wrong side of the way the president sees events in Afghanistan, what happened over the weekend. The wrong side in where the president wants to deal with Iran.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yeah. I mean, let's just go back. So I was spokesperson at the White House when John Bolton was trying to get confirmed to be U.S. ambassador. The U.S. Senate was like, heck no, that's not going to happen. Did anyone actually think he would last 17 months at the White House? It's a pretty good run, actually, if you think about it. He himself, when he took the job said, I'll give it my best shot, but if it ever comes to be that the president doesn't think I have -- if I don't have his confidence, then I'll be gone. That's why I think -- was he fired or did he resigned? It's a distinction without a difference. He is no longer there. One of the other things about this job is that you have to be an honest broker and beloved and trusted by everybody at the policy council. So, that's all sorts of people. That's the intelligence committee, state department, it's the Pentagon, it's DIA, it's all these different people. And you then have to take all their points and all of their advice and funnel it up to the president, and then make your best advice. And if that doesn't work anymore, then you can move on. So, I think whoever the president decides to get in there I think -- having somebody that knows how to run that process, just from a good governance standpoint will probably help him land some of those planes that are in the air.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It does raise a question, Kennedy, about who would take the job because it looks like --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, there's many.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, you think so?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I don't know who it would be, but like who -- who want to be national security advisor where there's -- they're probably lining up.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't think so. I think that there're lots of people who are concerned, and the question would be like, we don't have a national homeland security advisor at the moment. National security -- director of national intelligence is open. So, Kennedy, is that put America in danger to have all these openings in a sense of chaos?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: No, we already have too much government as it is. The president has plenty of advisors. I don't worry about that. And, you know, to Jesse's point, I'm not surprised that John Bolton clashed with everyone. I think he sees himself as oil and everyone else is water. He's very confident in his philosophical and academic perspective. And he's willing to go out on a limb and convince whoever his audience is whether it's the president or the secretary of state, whoever that is, that his worldview is the correct one. And you definitely want that kind of confidence. But mostly, people want that in a president. So I actually wouldn't be surprised to see John Bolton launch his candidacy for the presidency --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, you remember he ran in -- was it 2015?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: He still got Bolton pack. He still got Bolton pack. It is -- I don't know how well staff and functioning it is, but I know the man has a grand vision and I wouldn't be surprised at all.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wow, that's interesting. You know, Kennedy, -- I didn't have that thought. You think that's real?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: I don't know. This is pure speculation on my part --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK. No, no --

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: -- but given some of his past statements, given the fact that he's very ambitious, and he wanted to get his hooks into this administration for obvious reasons. And, you know now, it didn't work out. He's not going to compromise. He's not going gently. A lot of people when they leave the White House say this has been the greatest privilege of my life.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, he didn't say that.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: I love serving this president. He's like, I resigned. I was not fired. He's not afraid of interpersonal conflict.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, but he was the president's choice, Dana, but anyway. Tom, I just want to come to you on this one. General Mattis is gone. Tillerson's gone. Scaramucci's gone. Mike Flynn is gone.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I thought he was hiring the best people.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.sentences: We're hearing about all the people that left instead of the real headline which is I can't believe this guy lasted as long as he did. I happen to be filling in for someone called Kennedy. I was pitch sitting on your show, Kennedy, the day he was announced as national security advisor. And, boy, I felt like a real journalist. It was the first interview on Fox Business.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.sentences: It was a good interview, but I pressed him. I said, you don't agree with Trump on foreign policy. And he said I serve at the pleasure of the president. He kept repeating that line over and over again. We knew he was going to clash with the president. He likes clashing with the president. He lasted longer than he should have, Juan.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: He's no Ben Carson.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: Ben Carson is still there. Betsy DeVos. Rick Perry. No one talks about them.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK, Kennedy. President Trump going after Democrats at a very fiery rally in North Carolina. You've got to stay because you want to see the best highlights from that rally, it's up next on The Five.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: President Trump unloading on Democrats at a rally ahead of today's pivotal special election in North Carolina's ninth congressional district. Republican Dan Bishop is facing off against Democrat Dan McCready in a race many see as a preview of 2020. The president urging voters to back Bishop, while also slamming Democrats progressive policies. Watch him here.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: A vote for any Democrat in 2020, and a vote for any Democrat tomorrow in North Carolina is a vote for the rise of radical socialism and the destruction of the American dream. I wouldn't mind fighting the Democrats, but we really have to look at it as a twosome, it's the media and the Democrats. It's one and the same. They tried to do the recession thing. You know, they tried the Russia thing. That didn't work. They tried many other things.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, the president in his element last night. Juan, I just wanted to talk about North Carolina for just a moment before we go to a couple of other quick sound bites from the rally, which were incredible and very fun. Voter fraud is an issue that led to this special election. Special election, usually low voter turnout. You've got North Carolina just coming through the hurricane. What do you expect could happen there? We know that North Carolina is going to be a place that all of the candidates are gonna go. Democrats are going to try to flip that like Obama did in 2008, but the president is going to be there all the time, including at his convention.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Right. So what's interesting to me is I think the president won this by 12 percentage -- won North Carolina by 12 percentage points in 2016.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: This district.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And any in this district as their key point. But suddenly, he's there, and he's there was some anxiety. One, I guess, as you pointed out, there was voter fraud in that Mark Harris campaign or Republicans campaign, and so you get the board of elections saying we have to have a redo. That's what we're going through today. And right now, the poll shows them tide. It's --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The Democrats feel pretty good about tying it?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: They do. Dan McCready turns out to be a pretty good candidate, pretty young, energetic candidates. Dan Bishop, the reason the president is there is he wants to bolster Bishop in a time when, you know, with the economy slowing, all these questions, you know. He doesn't seem to be --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Smart for him to go, Kennedy, because -- I think, I should say, smart for the president to go because whether he went down there and campaigned or didn't, no matter what the outcome is, everybody was going to point to President Trump for the win or the loss.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. And, you know, going there -- he's in full election mode. This is one of the swing states as you pointed out. He only won the state by 4 percentage points. And there are a lot of Dan's in this race.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: There's a lot of Dan's

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: And Dan McCready, the Democrat, he wants to beat the Bishop. I don't know if he's going to be able to do that. But Democrats -- if he comes within 2 or 3 points, they will consider that a victory.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: They will. Can we play this other sound bite?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Sure. You don't need my permission.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. I don't need his permission, but I like to ask you because I admire you. Jesse, listen to this. This is the president talking about light.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I'm not a vain person. I know I have no vain people, especially these incredible ladies in the front. But I look better under an incandescent light than these crazy lights that are beaming down on.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Lighting, very critical.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The president, you know, he knows that. He's in the TV world.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, I'm not a vain person. The media already fact-checked that false.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Adding to the list.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We were just talking about -- we both agree. We all look better with incandescent lights.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yet, I guess, they're bad for the environment.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But, I mean, how bad are they? Because we really need to look good.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And, America, you know what we've done? We done some -- a great job of innovating so you have more efficient lighting and it's also less expensive, and also we can still look good.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.sentences: Yes, but we don't like to be told and that's why this is a good issue for him. He saying the government is telling you, you can't have your old light bulbs. So even people who don't have a preference, they don't like the idea that the government is mandating it, so he's going to keep talking about this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You know there's a black market for the incandescent bulbs. I just found out about it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: Black market, Dana Perino. She's got steamer trunks full of that. She flips it open on Sixth Avenue.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Every time - I mean the - look, that was announced in 2007, when they raised the standard and every time Peter would go to the store for - let's say, by the way pick up some of those light bulbs, because you don't know how long we're going to have them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You've been stockpiling them. How much do they cost in the black market, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We're going to have to save that for one of your supermarket's showdown.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'll have to take a better guess.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: At that point. All right. The president's rally now behind us, next. Monopoly getting a makeover that has a lot of conservatives upset, but not outraged. Find out why when we return.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: What a night. Get ready for woke monopoly. Yes, you heard me. The classic board game getting a liberal makeover and it's all being done in the name of empowering women. Unlike the original in monopoly. Female players will collect 240 bucks for passing go. The fellows just kept 200. Hasbro saying it's "a fun new take on the game that creates a world where women have an advantage often enjoyed by men. But don't worry if men play their cards right. They can make more money too." This is so patronizing as though women are victims and they need help from monopoly because everywhere else in the world they can't compete. Well, like when you play the game. Please tell me what is the advantage that any male player has over a female player. There is none. It's one of the best things about the game. You pick your game piece and there is strategy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And then you roll the dice and then you have to think, and you have to be the banker and you have to like - it's a great game that teaches a lot of things. This is unnecessary. You'll get plenty of this when you get to campus. They will tell you all the reasons why you are not good enough. MONTGOMERY: Jesse, you have daughters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: Are you going to buy the Miss Monopoly so they can finally have an equal foothold. WATTERS: No. I bet Beto O'Rourke has already bought this game though. This is right up his alley. I challenge you guys to play me in the New Woke monopoly and I still will win, and I will tell you how I will do it. I will self-identify as a female just for the game in order to make myself even and then I will unidentified. But how woke that can go. I mean they could have all white male Republican players do not get to play there get out of jail free card. I mean you could take this as far as you want. Pay twice as many as taxes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Tell Manafort that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Exactly. That's why we have to correct it for the game. Like you said, it was already even.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.sentences: It's already even,

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Now they're just trying to punish men.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY

utterances.utterance: Let's be clear, lives could still be in danger, maybe even more so now. This is supposed to be a news story, not an episode of the Americans. And I understand the frustration of the Central Intelligence Agency. CIA hardly ever comments on anything. Now, if you call a reporter on background and you say, hey, I've got this tip. What do you think about? Now, one of the things the CIA communications person might say is, I am telling you off the record, you are wrong. You will be embarrassed if you print that. Don't go with it. I'm waving you off the story. Or you might say, I have no comment for you on that and I will let you know if I ever do. Those two things can give you some clarification. Sounds to me like the CIA and the State Department are both very much on the same page saying this did not happened. We also know that Putin has not been shy about punishing his enemies or former spies. Let's go to Britain and we'll roll the tape and you've got problems there. It not only hurts the people that are targeted, but those around them because of the poison that they have used. So this is extremely dangerous. Disappointed -- I don't know what happened there with all of the reporting, but obviously, it was not good enough.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, Juan, what do you think happened? And do you think the leaks are real but the news is wrong?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.utterance: No. I think -- this is really interesting. I really appreciate what Dana had to say, because I think what Dana just told you is an insight into how public, you know, press secretary handle reporters when we're asking these kinds of questions on sensitive stories. They basically tell you if you're right or wrong. So CNN breaks the story. The story is then followed up by the New York Times and the Washington Post. Russia's state-sponsored media also at that point says they have the name of this spy. The New York Times in their reporting, which comes after, separate from the CNN story. And the New York Times, by the way, said the CNN story was wrong. But the New York Times said, we've checked with someone like a Dana Perino, and they didn't wave us off this story. They said, go ahead. So that tells you that there is basis to the reality of this person, this spy, former -- apparently someone who was high up in the Russian government, close enough to Putin to have access to documents that he could then -- not only see, but in some cases photograph and sent to the U.S. And then you get the general anxiety that comes after Trump's meeting in 2017 with the Russian ambassador and the Russian foreign minister. That's a separate issue. Initially, this guy was tried -- they tried to, what they call, expatriate this man in 2016 after Washington Post, New York Times story said the U.S. government has a source inside the Kremlin.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They -- he refused to leave. But then, there's this increased anxiety after the Trump oval office meeting with the Russians, and then the guy agrees to leave and he's pulled. But it's not because of Trump.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, again, it's not Trump putting national security at risk, Kennedy. It's the media.

utterances.speaker: LISA KENNEDY MONTGOMERY, HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, and we're also taking a leap there. And, you know, there may have been something untoward and not right about that meeting. There may have been something very un-presidential about the president's comportment in that meeting. That doesn't mean that the president somehow reveal the identity of this asset in Russia to the ambassador when he was in the White House. And that is -- that is the unfortunate leap. And perhaps, that's the thing that takes time and clarification, because right now, for places like CNN, it's really, choose your own adventure. And if you get some facts that are not correlated or really directly tied to the ultimate conclusion, you just go ahead and make it up. You just go ahead and craft a bridge out of your own intentions, regardless of their truth or falsehood. And that's what's most dangerous. And I think part of it is this desire to bring the president down and really pin something on him. Because, you know, your intuition is telling you that something is not right. It could be your hurt feelings. However, you know, going ahead and just throwing anything at him, regardless of facts, it's dangerous.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And Rush Limbaugh weigh in earlier about how all this Russia reporting has affected the media.

utterances.speaker: RUSH LIMBAUGH, TALK SHOW HOST
utterances.utterance: I think that that little episode is going to have a price that they're not even calculating. There will be a price to pay for this. And the Democrats are seen as being responsible for it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Tom Shillue, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: TOM SHILLUE, HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, I would hope that Rush is right about that, but there never seems to be a price for it. And, you know, they don't seem to think there's a price for it, because they keep doing these stories. They keep wanting to reopen these Russia things. So -- and you know what, the rest of the mainstream media lets them get away with it. They always say, well, that ship has sailed. The Russia story is over. I mean, it's a massive scandal and I think President Trump, he's going to try to make hay out of this and we're going to be talking about it later on the show. And his rally last night, he was talking about the Democrats and the media together. There a twosome. And that's what he's talking about that the Democrats and the media are -- have been acting as one, and he's going to use that when he runs against them in 2020.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The other thing is -- you're not solid on this and you go with it. That aside -- for a second, think of how amazing our intelligence agencies are, that they were able to get this asset that close.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All around the world. And I understand the appeal to want to report on one of these stores. I don't know how far up they went. Right now, if the CIA said, you know, go ahead. I don't know. Well, I would -- I would want to track that down and just see. And maybe they thought that they couldn't comment on it or they're trying to protect the identity. There's so many things that you don't know. But the dangers of it hurting other national security efforts I think to me are so great. I would air on the side of caution.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Well, and also, you bring up a really good point and that is, you know, we have relied so much on things like drones and mass surveillance and not enough on human beings and cultivating those relationships. And it doesn't matter who the administration is or who the president is, those things take time and we do need to cultivate those assets more and more around the world. And also, every time we focus on Russia, we really take our eyes off of other countries who might be trying to infiltrate our elections and our voting systems based on the road map that Russia laid out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, lastly, do you think that CNN should apologize and retracts the way that Lawrence O'Donnell had to with his other fake Russia reporting two weeks ago.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, it's totally different, Jesse, in the sense that Lawrence O'Donnell -- I think he said he had one source that wouldn't go on the record and it was very flimsy. I just -- I don't think that was journalism.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: It is similar. I mean, that's what he said. According to a person familiar with the talks, that was all I saw in the CNN article that I read according to a person familiar with the talks.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't believe that.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: It's one flimsy source.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't believe that, but if it's the case, then that would be flimsy, Tom. But I don't believe that they would have --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean, it's a pattern, Juan. I mean, they reported that Don Jr. has access to WikiLeaks when he didn't have access prior to the release. They fired several reporters from their investigative unit over the false reporting about Scaramucci ties to Russia --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, and also -- if you're looking at the media writ large as Rush Limbaugh was doing, you remember the story was Lawrence O'Donnell just a couple of weeks ago, but that was MSNBC in which they went with a single source and then he has to apologize the next day, oh, I shouldn't have done that. It was also Russia related.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But here's the thing to me. I think what you hear from the intelligence agency, they didn't like the presidents meeting with the Russians in the oval office. That's for sure. Then a couple of weeks ago it's the president tweeting out a picture of an Iranian site and saying, oh, he knows and people like -- isn't that classified, Mr. President? What are you doing?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But he gets to decide.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He's the one who decides, but --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- but for the intelligence agencies, Dana, they're worried. They're saying, hey, can you trust this president to protect us and to protect our assets. Here's the thing I want to say to you, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Now that we know so clearly about this person, this spy, working for the United States at the upper reaches of Putin's government, we know that there was far more than the Steele dossier, far more than anything we've known before in terms of proof that the United States government had about Russian interference in the 2016 election being directed by Vladimir Putin, and the basis therefore for an investigation, not only into Russian interference but into Russian ties to --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm glad you brought that up, Juan, because --

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: -- President Obama revealed some of that earlier.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, Juan, I'm glad you brought that up because we're now looking at testimony that proves that the Steele dossier was the basis for launching --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, it wasn't. Obviously not. Obviously not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- the FBI counterintelligence investigation into the Trump campaign. You'll see, Juan. Coming up, a shake-up in the White House, the breaking details ahead.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A major shake-up at the White House today. John Bolton is out as national security advisor. And now, he's in a back-and-forth with the president about how it happened. Trump tweeted earlier that he fired Bolton. But Bolton, he quickly responded that he wasn't fired, instead he said he resigned. Who's telling the truth here, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't know what's happened. But, I mean, the guy has had a very good career, very well respected, professional guy, but it just didn't work out. It had been shimmering for a long time. It was probably personality and a little ideology. He didn't play well with a lot of people in the sandbox. Academics sometimes don't. He didn't have a lot of allies. He clashed with Pompeo. He clashed with Mike Pence. So, sorry, that role as national security advisor too, you're in close contact with the President of the United States often in the oval office. And you have to be able to mesh. I don't think he meshed. And what the president wanted was someone to implement his policies, execute his strategies and his directives. And it seemed like a lot of the times, Bolton was saying, oh, well, you know what, this is why my ideas better, and that's just not going to work. There's three huge things that are on the horizon, the president needs to turn the page on in foreign policy, the China trade deal, Afghanistan, and Iran. And all those three things he's gonna need seasoned pro that can navigate those three things without a lot of turbulence and land that plane, because next year, year and a half, two years is going to be big.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, Dana, I think lots of people saw John Bolton as a strong conservative voice in the administration. I think the president hired him for just that reason. And now, it turns out, he's on the wrong side of the way the president sees events in Afghanistan, what happened over the weekend. The wrong side in where the president wants to deal with Iran.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I mean, let's just go back. So I was spokesperson at the White House when John Bolton was trying to get confirmed to be U.S. ambassador. The U.S. Senate was like, heck no, that's not going to happen. Did anyone actually think he would last 17 months at the White House? It's a pretty good run, actually, if you think about it. He himself, when he took the job said, I'll give it my best shot, but if it ever comes to be that the president doesn't think I have -- if I don't have his confidence, then I'll be gone. That's why I think -- was he fired or did he resigned? It's a distinction without a difference. He is no longer there. One of the other things about this job is that you have to be an honest broker and beloved and trusted by everybody at the policy council. So, that's all sorts of people. That's the intelligence committee, state department, it's the Pentagon, it's DIA, it's all these different people. And you then have to take all their points and all of their advice and funnel it up to the president, and then make your best advice. And if that doesn't work anymore, then you can move on. So, I think whoever the president decides to get in there I think -- having somebody that knows how to run that process, just from a good governance standpoint will probably help him land some of those planes that are in the air.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It does raise a question, Kennedy, about who would take the job because it looks like --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, there's many.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, you think so?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know who it would be, but like who -- who want to be national security advisor where there's -- they're probably lining up.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't think so. I think that there're lots of people who are concerned, and the question would be like, we don't have a national homeland security advisor at the moment. National security -- director of national intelligence is open. So, Kennedy, is that put America in danger to have all these openings in a sense of chaos?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: No, we already have too much government as it is. The president has plenty of advisors. I don't worry about that. And, you know, to Jesse's point, I'm not surprised that John Bolton clashed with everyone. I think he sees himself as oil and everyone else is water. He's very confident in his philosophical and academic perspective. And he's willing to go out on a limb and convince whoever his audience is whether it's the president or the secretary of state, whoever that is, that his worldview is the correct one. And you definitely want that kind of confidence. But mostly, people want that in a president. So I actually wouldn't be surprised to see John Bolton launch his candidacy for the presidency --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, you remember he ran in -- was it 2015?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: He still got Bolton pack. He still got Bolton pack. It is -- I don't know how well staff and functioning it is, but I know the man has a grand vision and I wouldn't be surprised at all.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow, that's interesting. You know, Kennedy, -- I didn't have that thought. You think that's real?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: I don't know. This is pure speculation on my part --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. No, no --

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: -- but given some of his past statements, given the fact that he's very ambitious, and he wanted to get his hooks into this administration for obvious reasons. And, you know now, it didn't work out. He's not going to compromise. He's not going gently. A lot of people when they leave the White House say this has been the greatest privilege of my life.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, he didn't say that.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: I love serving this president. He's like, I resigned. I was not fired. He's not afraid of interpersonal conflict.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, but he was the president's choice, Dana, but anyway. Tom, I just want to come to you on this one. General Mattis is gone. Tillerson's gone. Scaramucci's gone. Mike Flynn is gone.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I thought he was hiring the best people.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: We're hearing about all the people that left instead of the real headline which is I can't believe this guy lasted as long as he did. I happen to be filling in for someone called Kennedy. I was pitch sitting on your show, Kennedy, the day he was announced as national security advisor. And, boy, I felt like a real journalist. It was the first interview on Fox Business.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: It was a good interview, but I pressed him. I said, you don't agree with Trump on foreign policy. And he said I serve at the pleasure of the president. He kept repeating that line over and over again. We knew he was going to clash with the president. He likes clashing with the president. He lasted longer than he should have, Juan.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: He's no Ben Carson.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Ben Carson is still there. Betsy DeVos. Rick Perry. No one talks about them.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK, Kennedy. President Trump going after Democrats at a very fiery rally in North Carolina. You've got to stay because you want to see the best highlights from that rally, it's up next on The Five.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: President Trump unloading on Democrats at a rally ahead of today's pivotal special election in North Carolina's ninth congressional district. Republican Dan Bishop is facing off against Democrat Dan McCready in a race many see as a preview of 2020. The president urging voters to back Bishop, while also slamming Democrats progressive policies. Watch him here.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: A vote for any Democrat in 2020, and a vote for any Democrat tomorrow in North Carolina is a vote for the rise of radical socialism and the destruction of the American dream. I wouldn't mind fighting the Democrats, but we really have to look at it as a twosome, it's the media and the Democrats. It's one and the same. They tried to do the recession thing. You know, they tried the Russia thing. That didn't work. They tried many other things.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, the president in his element last night. Juan, I just wanted to talk about North Carolina for just a moment before we go to a couple of other quick sound bites from the rally, which were incredible and very fun. Voter fraud is an issue that led to this special election. Special election, usually low voter turnout. You've got North Carolina just coming through the hurricane. What do you expect could happen there? We know that North Carolina is going to be a place that all of the candidates are gonna go. Democrats are going to try to flip that like Obama did in 2008, but the president is going to be there all the time, including at his convention.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right. So what's interesting to me is I think the president won this by 12 percentage -- won North Carolina by 12 percentage points in 2016.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: This district.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And any in this district as their key point. But suddenly, he's there, and he's there was some anxiety. One, I guess, as you pointed out, there was voter fraud in that Mark Harris campaign or Republicans campaign, and so you get the board of elections saying we have to have a redo. That's what we're going through today. And right now, the poll shows them tide. It's --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The Democrats feel pretty good about tying it?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They do. Dan McCready turns out to be a pretty good candidate, pretty young, energetic candidates. Dan Bishop, the reason the president is there is he wants to bolster Bishop in a time when, you know, with the economy slowing, all these questions, you know. He doesn't seem to be --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Smart for him to go, Kennedy, because -- I think, I should say, smart for the president to go because whether he went down there and campaigned or didn't, no matter what the outcome is, everybody was going to point to President Trump for the win or the loss.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Absolutely. And, you know, going there -- he's in full election mode. This is one of the swing states as you pointed out. He only won the state by 4 percentage points. And there are a lot of Dan's in this race.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There's a lot of Dan's

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: And Dan McCready, the Democrat, he wants to beat the Bishop. I don't know if he's going to be able to do that. But Democrats -- if he comes within 2 or 3 points, they will consider that a victory.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They will. Can we play this other sound bite?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Sure. You don't need my permission.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. I don't need his permission, but I like to ask you because I admire you. Jesse, listen to this. This is the president talking about light.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: I'm not a vain person. I know I have no vain people, especially these incredible ladies in the front. But I look better under an incandescent light than these crazy lights that are beaming down on.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Lighting, very critical.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The president, you know, he knows that. He's in the TV world.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I'm not a vain person. The media already fact-checked that false.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Adding to the list.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We were just talking about -- we both agree. We all look better with incandescent lights.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yet, I guess, they're bad for the environment.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But, I mean, how bad are they? Because we really need to look good.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And, America, you know what we've done? We done some -- a great job of innovating so you have more efficient lighting and it's also less expensive, and also we can still look good.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Yes, but we don't like to be told and that's why this is a good issue for him. He saying the government is telling you, you can't have your old light bulbs. So even people who don't have a preference, they don't like the idea that the government is mandating it, so he's going to keep talking about this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know there's a black market for the incandescent bulbs. I just found out about it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Black market, Dana Perino. She's got steamer trunks full of that. She flips it open on Sixth Avenue.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Every time - I mean the - look, that was announced in 2007, when they raised the standard and every time Peter would go to the store for - let's say, by the way pick up some of those light bulbs, because you don't know how long we're going to have them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You've been stockpiling them. How much do they cost in the black market, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We're going to have to save that for one of your supermarket's showdown.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'll have to take a better guess.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: At that point. All right. The president's rally now behind us, next. Monopoly getting a makeover that has a lot of conservatives upset, but not outraged. Find out why when we return.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: What a night. Get ready for woke monopoly. Yes, you heard me. The classic board game getting a liberal makeover and it's all being done in the name of empowering women. Unlike the original in monopoly. Female players will collect 240 bucks for passing go. The fellows just kept 200. Hasbro saying it's "a fun new take on the game that creates a world where women have an advantage often enjoyed by men. But don't worry if men play their cards right. They can make more money too." This is so patronizing as though women are victims and they need help from monopoly because everywhere else in the world they can't compete. Well, like when you play the game. Please tell me what is the advantage that any male player has over a female player. There is none. It's one of the best things about the game. You pick your game piece and there is strategy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And then you roll the dice and then you have to think, and you have to be the banker and you have to like - it's a great game that teaches a lot of things. This is unnecessary. You'll get plenty of this when you get to campus. They will tell you all the reasons why you are not good enough. MONTGOMERY: Jesse, you have daughters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Are you going to buy the Miss Monopoly so they can finally have an equal foothold. WATTERS: No. I bet Beto O'Rourke has already bought this game though. This is right up his alley. I challenge you guys to play me in the New Woke monopoly and I still will win, and I will tell you how I will do it. I will self-identify as a female just for the game in order to make myself even and then I will unidentified. But how woke that can go. I mean they could have all white male Republican players do not get to play there get out of jail free card. I mean you could take this as far as you want. Pay twice as many as taxes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Tell Manafort that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Exactly. That's why we have to correct it for the game. Like you said, it was already even.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: It's already even,

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Now they're just trying to punish men.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Here's the problem, they are going to punish men, but this is very CIS normative.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Because you're assuming that there are two genders, male and female. And what if I don't identify into one of those deplorable baskets. My own gender identification. I feel very left out of this.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I love it that you're taking this so seriously. I think look, if the conservatives want to buy the game, they believe in free markets, buy the game. You don't want to buy it, don't buy it. But I will say I think this is kind of interesting because what they're saying is, hey, stop and think about the realities, like they instead of being real estate purchases, right and real estate as we know is all dominated by white males. They say, hey, look, you can invest in inventions made by women. And I looked it up, it was like things like bullet proof vest and chocolate chip cookies and Wi-Fi invented by women.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You don't think women do well in real estate. could do well. You don't think women are well represented in real estate?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You look around New York, Manhattan real estate, it's almost a total white guy.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: But there is a whole country out there.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I'm talking.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: New York.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. Well, I'm just talking about where I know, New York, Washington, Philadelphia. I don't see many women at the top of that.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: All right, NAR.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Liz Keenan, specific Palisades California.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: All we get is an extra--

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Tom Shillue.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: An extra 40 bucks isn't going to do it anyway. That's not as much of an advantage. You could - I think it'd be interesting try to play against them getting the extra 40 bucks. I still think I'd win.
